lines.text: You know that I'm not a man that's easily shaken, Dr. Landers.
I know that. I know. Now, would you like a drink?
No, no-no. I've just seen somethin', and by all that's holy... I just can't be sure, but... I think it's Ian Bellows.
You THINK it's Ian? What's happened to him?
I-I don't know. His body's all like... like jelly.
Jelly?
Aye. It's like nothin' I've ever seen. There was no face, just a... horrible... mush... with the eyes sittin' in it.
Is that all, then, Ian?
Yeah, I think so. And how long will it take to fill the order THIS time, eh?
Oh, probably three to four weeks.
Aye, y'know, they ought to give us better service. And a boat coming once a week is not enough! You'd think at least they'd get our telephones installed.
Y'know, they promised 'em this year.

[chuckles]
Aye, and last.
What the devil did Napoleon do on that island of his to keep himself busy?
He invented solitaire.

[suggestively]
I've a much better game in mind.
Can three play?
John.
Aye.
I just found one of my horses dead. At least, I think it's one of my horses. It's all soft and flabby.

[flirting]
I may not get places as fast as a Maserati...
...but you do get there eventually, don't you?
Eventually.
When?
I'll let you know.
Don't wait too long. You might run out of petrol on the last lap.
[arriving at the mansion]
Toni, you stay in the car.
I'm not staying here with all those things running around.
Oh, let her come. I wouldn't want to stay out here alone. It's too damn creepy.
[Stanley strays a bit too far from the main group]
Brian, hold it! Come back to the car. If there is something in there, we better not get too close until we know what we're up against.
What do you think is in there?
I don't know, but let's not take any unnecessary risks.
No, especially with me!
The potential across the cell membrane must be maintained during irradiation of the nucleus. Is the tri-chem stage complete?
Yes.
And the, uh, vapor-applicator?
It's been corrected. The histo-connect problem has been solved. There shouldn't be any snags.

Good. Now that we've received the infusion equipment, well, I'm certain they will understand my reason for going ahead. I've waited a long time for this moment. If we're successful today, it may well be that we have the cure for cancer.

[sarcastically]
One more transfusion and I'll be a full-blooded Irishman.
You know what? It-it smells like fog.
Nonsense. I think it's going to be a lovely evening.
Ah, if you weren't a newcomer you'd feel it in your bones.
A newcomer? I've been here for ten years!
You're a newcomer, just the same.
We got to get out of here.
Where can we go? We can't reach the mainland.
Look. If you'd seen what I've seen at two in the morning, you'd swim for it!
Halsey! Shut up.

[to the crowd]
Listen, all of you. If anyone leaves this building, they'll be killed for sure. Now, we're safe enough in here; we've got enough food and water to wait.
I'm so frightened, Mr. Campbell.
Now, if you do as we say, you've got nothing to fear. Will you trust me?
Yes, sir.

[drags Halsey aside]
Now listen, Halsey, and listen well. If I hear another sound out of you, I'm going to smash your face in and throw you out for those things to get. Now I'm talking to you straight, man. Do you understand?
Mr. Campbell, I can't stand any more...
Do. You. Understand? Mind that you do.
More books, Doctor?
You islanders are too hardy. I have to do something to keep busy.
You know, Doctor, you and I should take up chess. I've got nothing to do either, except when Andy McCracken has a wee drop too much and tries to break up the pub.
Science has its risks, but the risks aren't enough to hinder progress.
